answer_html: \(y(x)=a_0 x^{\frac{1}{2}} - \frac{1}{10} a_0 x^{\frac{3}{2}} + \frac{3}{280} a_0 x^{\frac{5}{2}} + \cdots\)
hints_html:
This is a standard question in this course. If you have forgotten how to do this type of question, check your class notes or homework for a similar example.

Is \(x = 0\) an ordinary point or a singular point?

Compare the ODE with

\[\begin{aligned} P(x) y'' + Q(x) y' + R(x) y = 0.\end{aligned}\]

We see that \(P(x) = 2 x^2\). Since \(P(x) = 0\) when \(x = 0\), \(x =0\) is a singular point.

Is \(x = 0\) a regular singular point or an irregular singular point?

Again compare the ODE with

\[\begin{aligned} P(x) y'' + Q(x) y' + R(x) y = 0.\end{aligned}\]

We see that \(P(x) = 2 x^2\), \(Q(x) = 3x + x^2\) and \(R(x) = -1\). Now,

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0} x \frac{Q(x)}{P(x)} = \lim_{x \to 0} x \frac{3 x + x^2}{2 x^2} = \lim_{x \to 0} (\frac{3}{2} + \frac{1}{2} x) \;\; \text{is finite}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0} x^2 \frac{R(x)}{P(x)} = \lim_{x \to 0} x^2 \frac{-1}{2 x^2} = - \frac{1}{2} \;\; \text{is finite} .\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, \(x = 0\) is a regular singular point.

Should we consider series solutions of the form

\[\begin{aligned} y(x) = \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n x^n \;\; \text{or} \;\; y(x) = \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n x^{n+r} ?\end{aligned}\]

sols_html:
Following the comments in the hints, we see that \(x = 0\) is a regular singular point. Therefore, we should look for series solutions of the form

\[\begin{aligned} y = \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n x^{n+r} .\end{aligned}\]

We have that

\[\begin{aligned} y = \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n x^{n+r}, \; y' = \sum_{{\color{red} n = 0}}^\infty a_n (n+r) x^{n+r-1}, \; y'' = \sum_{{\color{red} n = 0}}^\infty a_n (n+r) (n+r-1)x^{n+r-2} .\end{aligned}\]

(Please note that the both of the sums for \(y'\) and \(y''\) start at \(n=0\).)

Substitute these into the ODE

\[\begin{aligned} 2 x^2 y'' + (3x + x^2) y' - y = 0,\end{aligned}\]

we get that

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n = 0}^\infty 2 a_n (n+r)(n+r-1) x^{n+r} + \sum_{n = 0}^\infty 3 a_n (n+r) x^{n+r} {\color{blue} + \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n (n+r) x^{n+r+1}} + \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n x^{n+r} = 0.\end{aligned}\]

We should shift the index \(n\) of \({\color{blue} \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n (n+r)x^{n+r+1}}\) so the order of \(x\) matches with the other terms. To do so, we should replace every \(n\) with \(n-1\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue} \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n (n+r) x^{n+r+1} } = \sum_{ n = {\color{red}1} }^\infty a_{ n {\color{red}-1} } (n+r {\color{red} -1} ) x^{ {\color{red} n+r}} .\end{aligned}\]

Then we have

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n = 0}^\infty 2 a_n (n+r)(n+r-1) x^{n+r} + \sum_{n = 0}^\infty 3 a_n (n+r) x^{n+r} {\color{red} + \sum_{n = 1}^\infty a_{n-1} (n+r-1) x^{n+r}} + \sum_{n = 0}^\infty a_n x^{n+r} = 0\end{aligned}\]

which, after separating the \(n = 0\) terms, can be rewritten as

\[\begin{aligned} [2 a_0 r(r-1) + 3 a_0 r - a_0] \; x^r + \sum_{n = 1}^\infty \; {\color{OliveGreen} [2 a_n (n+r)(n+r-1) + 3 a_n (n+r) + a_{n-1} (n+r-1) + a_n]} \;x^{n+r} = 0.\end{aligned}\]

Look at the above equation, because the right hand side is 0, the coefficient of the \(x^r\) term must be 0 as well. Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} [2 a_0 r(r-1) + 3 a_0 r - a_0] = a_0 (2r(r-1) + 3 r - 1) = 0. \,\end{aligned}\]

Now, if \(a_0 = 0\), then all the subsequent \(a_n\) will be zero as well and we only get the trivial solution \(y =0\). (Why? You can verify that yourself after we finish the question. Set \(a_0 = 0\) and you will see the other terms will be forced to be 0 by the recursion relation.) In other words, we must have

\[\begin{aligned} 2r(r-1) + 3 r - 1 = 2r^2 + r - 1 = (2r-1) (r+1) = 0 \,\end{aligned}\]

giving us two roots \(r = \frac{1}{2}\) and \(r = -1 \,\). (Note: In the above, \(2r(r-1) + 3 r - 1 = 0\) is known as the indicial equation.)

By the same reason as \([2 a_0 r(r-1) + 3 a_0 r - a_0] = 0\), we have that

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{OliveGreen} [2 a_n (n+r)(n+r-1) + 3 a_n (n+r) + a_{n-1} (n+r-1) + a_n]} = 0 \;\; \text{foreach} \;\; n \geq 1. \,\end{aligned}\]

If we Isolate \(a_{n}\), we get the recurrence relation

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = \frac{-(n+r-1) a_{n-1}}{2(n+r)(n+r-1) + 3(n+r) -1} \;\; \text{for} \;\; n \geq 1 .\end{aligned}\]

After simplifying and factoring the expression in the denominator, the above expression can be rewritten as

\[\begin{aligned} a_n = \frac{-(n+r-1) a_{n-1}}{2(n+r)^2 + (n+r) -1} = \frac{-(n+r-1) a_{n-1}}{(2(n+r) -1)((n+r)+1)}\end{aligned}\]

which may be easier to do calculations with.

Now recall that from the indicial equation, we found \(r = \frac{1}{2}\) and \(r = -1 \,\).

In the case \(r = -1 \,\), \(y = \sum_{n =0}^\infty a_n x^{n-1} = a_0 x^{-1} + a_1 + a_2 x + \cdots\).

Note that the above equation does not satisfy \(\lim_{x \to 0^+} y(x) = 0\) due to the \(a_0 x^{-1}\) term, so the expression corresponding to \(r = -1\) is not what the question is asking for.

In the case \(r = \frac{1}{2}\) , \(y = \sum_{n =0}^\infty a_n x^{n+\frac{1}{2}} = a_0 x^{\frac{1}{2}} + a_1 x^{\frac{3}{2}} + a_2 x^{\frac{5}{2}} + \cdots\).

Note that the above equation satisfies \(\lim_{x \to 0^+} y(x) = 0\). In other words, this is the one the question is asking for.

It remains to find \(a_1\) and \(a_2\) in terms of \(a_0\). To find \(a_1\), substitue \(n = 1 \,\) and \(r = \frac{1}{2}\) into the recurrence relation. We get that

\[\begin{aligned} a_1 = \frac{-(1 + \frac{1}{2} - 1) a_0}{(2(1+\frac{1}{2})-1)(1+\frac{1}{2}+1)} = \frac{-1}{10} a_0 .\end{aligned}\]

To find \(a_2\), substitue \(n = 2 \,\) and \(r = \frac{1}{2}\) into the recurrence relation. We get that

\[\begin{aligned} a_2 = \frac{-(2 + \frac{1}{2} - 1) a_1}{(2(2+\frac{1}{2})-1)(2 +\frac{1}{2}+1)} = \frac{-3}{28} a_1 = \frac{-3}{28} (\frac{-1}{10} a_0) = \frac{3}{280} a_0 .\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we have

\[\begin{aligned} y(x) = a_0 x^{\frac{1}{2}} + a_1 x^{\frac{3}{2}} + a_2 x^{\frac{5}{2}} + \cdots= a_0 x^{\frac{1}{2}} - \frac{1}{10} a_0 x^{\frac{3}{2}} + \frac{3}{280} a_0 x^{\frac{5}{2}} + \cdots\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
For the ordinary differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} 2 x^2 y'' + (3x + x^2) y' - y = 0 , \,\end{aligned}\]

find the first 3 terms of a non-zero series solution about \(x = 0\) satisfying

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0^+} y(x) = 0.\end{aligned}\]
